articles.title: Songun Politics of WPK Praised by Foreign Figure
Proposal for Founding DFRK Supported
WPK Birthday Celebrated in Different Countries
articles.content:
Proposal for Founding DFRK Supported 
    Pyongyang, October 18 (KCNA) -- Jorge Bornhausen, chairman of the Party of Liberal Front of Brazil, warmly congratulated the Workers' Party of Korea on its 60th birthday when he met DPRK Ambassador to his country Pak Hyok on Oct. 10.
 Supporting the proposal for founding the Democratic Federal Republic of Koryo set forth by President Kim Il Sung, he noted his party hoped the Korean people would achieve the independent and peaceful reunification of Korea free from foreign interference.

Greetings to Azerbaijani President

articles.content:
Greetings to Azerbaijani President
    Pyongyang, October 18 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, Tuesday sent a message of greetings to Ilham Aliyev, president of the Azerbaijan Republic, on the occasion of its national day.
 Expressing the belief that the friendly and cooperative relations between the two countries would grow stronger, the message wished him greater success in his responsible work for the stability and prosperity of the country as well as welfare of the people.

articles.title: Roast Chestnuts and Sweet Potatos Popular in Pyongyang
articles.content:
Kim Yong Nam Receives Credentials from Cambodian Ambassador
    Pyongyang, October 18 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, received credentials from Chhorn Hay, Cambodian ambassador to the DPRK, at the Mansudae Assembly Hall on Tuesday. 
 On hand were Vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs Kim Yong Il and officials of the Cambodian embassy here.    
 After receiving the credentials the president had a conversation with the ambassador.

articles.content:
Roast Chestnuts and Sweet Potatos Popular in Pyongyang
    Pyongyang, October 18 (KCNA) -- Stalls along streets in Pyongyang are drawing customers for roast chestnuts and sweet potatoes these days.
 According to Kim Sung Thaek, a department director of the Ministry of Commerce, the commercial and catering service networks under the Pyongyang City Bureau for the Guidance of Public Service and the Pyongyang City People's Committee started serving roast chestnuts and sweat potatoes on the occasion of the 60th birthday of the Workers' Party of Korea. There are more than 310 roast chestnut and sweat potato stalls only in the main streets of the city, he added.    
 President Kim Il Sung instructed officials concerned to take measures for providing Pyongyang citizens with roast chestnuts and sweet potatoes.
 In order to carry it into practice leader Kim Jong Il saw to it that roast chestnut and sweat potato stalls have been set up in streets and chestnuts and sweat potatoes preferentially supplied to the city.    
 Amid such care, stalls never ceased to serve roast chestnuts and sweat potatoes even in the period of the "Arduous March" and the forced march.
 The odor of roast chestnuts and sweat potatoes is a unique flavor in Korea during autumn.
